More Data Types and Syntax

Your turn 1

Look at the R object WorldPhones (by typing its name in your notebook or the Console and hitting enter).

Vectors and matrices

vec <- c(1, 2, 3, 10, 100)
vec
[1]   1   2   3  10 100
mat <- matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow = 2)
mat
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
[2,]    2    4    6
matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow = 2)
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
[2,]    2    4    6
matrix(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), nrow = 3)
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    4
[2,]    2    5
[3,]    3    6

Math with vectors and matrices

vec + 4
[1]   5   6   7  14 104
vec * 4
[1]   4   8  12  40 400
vec * vec # element-wise multiplication
[1]     1     4     9   100 10000
vec %*% vec # matrix multiplication (inner)
      [,1]
[1,] 10114
vec %o% vec # matrix multiplication (outer)
     [,1] [,2] [,3] [,4]  [,5]
[1,]    1    2    3   10   100
[2,]    2    4    6   20   200
[3,]    3    6    9   30   300
[4,]   10   20   30  100  1000
[5,]  100  200  300 1000 10000
mat
     [,1] [,2] [,3]
[1,]    1    3    5
[2,]    2    4    6
t(mat) # transpose
     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    2
[2,]    3    4
[3,]    5    6

Arrays

array(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6), dim = c(2, 2, 3))
, , 1

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    1    3
[2,]    2    4

, , 2

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    5    1
[2,]    6    2

, , 3

     [,1] [,2]
[1,]    3    5
[2,]    4    6

Data types

Numeric

1 + 1
[1] 2
3000000
[1] 3e+06
class(0.00001)
[1] "numeric"

Character

"hello"
[1] "hello"
class("hello")
[1] "character"
"hello" + "world"
Error in "hello" + "world": non-numeric argument to binary operator
nchar("hello")
[1] 5
paste("hello", "world")
[1] "hello world"

Logical

3 > 4
[1] FALSE
class(TRUE)
[1] "logical"
class(T)
[1] "logical"

Factor (danger zone!)

fac <- factor(c("a", "b", "c"))
fac
[1] a b c
Levels: a b c
class(fac)
[1] "factor"

Your turn

Make a vector that contains the number 1, the letter R, and the logical TRUE

Quiz

What type of data will result?

Lists

lst <- list(1, "R", TRUE)
class(lst)
[1] "list"

Data frames

df <- data.frame(c(1, 2, 3), 
 c("R","S","T"), c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE))
class(df)
[1] "data.frame"

Naming

nvec <- c(one = 1, two = 2, three = 3)
nlst <- list(one = 1, two = 2, many = c(3, 4, 5))
ndf <- data.frame(numbers = c(1, 2, 3), 
          letters = c("R","S","T"), 
          logic = c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE))
names(ndf)
[1] "numbers" "letters" "logic"  
names(nvec)
[1] "one"   "two"   "three"

Subsetting

The dplyr way

To use the dplyr package, we need to load it.

library(dplyr)

Attaching package: 'dplyr'
The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':

    filter, lag
The following objects are masked from 'package:base':

    intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

Beatles data

Let’s make a toy dataset to play with.

beatles <- data.frame(
  name = c("John", "Paul", "George", "Ringo"),
  birth = c(1940, 1942, 1943, 1940), 
  instrument = c("guitar", "bass", "guitar", "drums")
)

Select

Select is a way to extract columns from dataframes

select(beatles, name, birth)
    name birth
1   John  1940
2   Paul  1942
3 George  1943
4  Ringo  1940

Your turn

Select just the instrument column

Base R

beatles[2,3]
[1] "bass"
beatles[ ,"birth"]
[1] 1940 1942 1943 1940
beatles[ ,c("name","birth")]
    name birth
1   John  1940
2   Paul  1942
3 George  1943
4  Ringo  1940
beatles$birth
[1] 1940 1942 1943 1940

Your turn

Select just the instrument column using brackets

Select just the instrument column using a dollar sign.

Filter

filter(beatles, name == "George")
    name birth instrument
1 George  1943     guitar

Your turn

More than one condition

filter(beatles, birth==1940, instrument == "guitar")
  name birth instrument
1 John  1940     guitar
filter(beatles, birth==1940 & instrument == "guitar")
  name birth instrument
1 John  1940     guitar

Your turn

Modify the code below to filter out the rows for which birth is 1943 or instrument is drums

filter(beatles, birth==1940 & instrument == "guitar")
  name birth instrument
1 John  1940     guitar

Base R

beatles[c(FALSE,TRUE,TRUE,FALSE), ]
    name birth instrument
2   Paul  1942       bass
3 George  1943     guitar
beatles[beatles$birth == 1940, ]
   name birth instrument
1  John  1940     guitar
4 Ringo  1940      drums

Your turn
